texts.shortText:
Beetles of the family Staphylinidae (‘rove beetles’) are fairly easily recognized as a group, in that most have elongate, narrow bodies and very short wing-covers, leaving the long abdomen largely exposed. However, many species are small and the family is very diverse, so species level identification can be challenging.

This species is larger than most, uniformly black, and fairly easily recognised by the very strongly punctate (dimpled) texture of the wing covers (elytra) and to a lesser extent of the abdomen, which also ends of an unusually long tuft of setae.

Global: Atlantic coasts of Europe and Africa, including Mediterranean and Baltic Sea.

Local/Regional: Not well known, but fairly common along west coast.

Little known about this species in South Africa other than that it restricted to the seashore and is regularly recorded among drift kelp. In Europe known to be a predator of kelp flies and of their larvae and abundance is correlated to that of the prey.
Feeds on kelp flies and their larvae.
The South African species has not been studied, but most staphylinids lay their eggs attached to objects in their habitat, such as kelp in this case. Their larvae are grub-like and also predatory.

Staphylinid beetles are extremely common in intertidal habitats and hundreds of coastal species are known globally. The South African fauna is poorly described and many species probably remain un-named. Although several other staphylinid species are found associated with rotting algae in the region this one is fairly easily recognized by its punctate elytra.

Frank, JH, & Ahn, KJ (2011). Coastal Staphylinidae (Coleoptera): A worldwide checklist, biogeography and natural history. ZooKeys, 107, 1-98.

Hodge, S & Williams, A (2007). Coleoptera found in wrack beds and strandlines around the Kent coast. British Journal of Entomology and Natural History, 20, 61-70.

Stenton-Dozey, JME, & Griffiths, CL (1983). The fauna associated with kelp stranded on a sandy beach. In Sandy beaches as ecosystems (pp. 557-568). Springer, Dordrecht.
